How to Stop Worrying in 6 Easy Steps

Life gets busy. For many of us, it moves so fast that we think our only option is to jump on that runaway train and go wherever it takes us. As a result, we feel stressed, anxious and panicky. But we do have a choice. We can choose mindfulness instead.

Do great work, you'll get a promotion and then you'll be happy. This is the mainstream formula for happiness. We're taught that working hard will lead to a great success and finally result in happiness. But happiness experts say our formula is wrong.

item.title: How meditation can help boost weight loss success
item.description:
How meditation can help boost weight loss success

When embarking on a diet, the focus is usually on healthy eating and exercise. Learning to manage emotions is rarely part of the regime, but growing research suggests it should be, as learning to breathe, focus, tune into the body, and avoid comfort eating during periods of emotional turmoil can help keep weight stable.

item.title: Mindfulness Exercises Even Cynics Will Want to Try
item.description:
Mindfulness Exercises Even Cynics Will Want to Try

It's easy to dismiss anything with a whiff of new-age BS to it, but several studies have found mindfulness to be effective for everything from pain relief to reducing stress, anxiety and depression. It helps you take control of your thoughts and stop worrying about inconsequential nonsense.

item.title: Research says adding this to family life can boost your child's well-being
item.description:
Research says adding this to family life can boost your child's well-being

"Mindfulness" is more than a buzzword that's promising great benefits to adults and children alike. Experts say that adding mindful activities to family routine can have lasting and specific positive impact on children, too, from improving relationships to boosting relaxation, calming anxiety and helping school performance.

item.title: 'Billions' Co-Creator Explains Why the Show's Characters Meditate
item.description:
'Billions' Co-Creator Explains Why the Show's Characters Meditate

In the pilot of the new Showtime series "Billions," a ruthless U.S. district attorney in New York ( Paul Giamatti) and an ambitious hedge fund billionaire ( Damian Lewis) are shown meditating. While seeing these two high-powered titans in such a calming state may seem unusual, "Billions" co-creator Brian Koppelman, 49, believes it works perfectly.
